p.s: As stated in the summary the speech Remarks of president Barack Obama at student roundtable is about building connections between different countries and cultures through student exchanges.
In the following, I will analyse which structure, stylistic devices and choice of words Barack uses, to convince the listeners on cross-cultural experiences.
The text is devideddivided into four main paragraphs.
In the first paragraph (l. 1-3), Obama tells, why he came to Turkey.
It is the shortest paragraph and it can be seen as an introduction.
Through this, the author creates tension and enlightens his audience with the (roughly) theme of his following speech.
The second paragraph (l. 1-12) deals with the passionate young civils of the USA, of which the president seems to be very proud.
That's why he wants to support them.
After that, Obama lists a few advantages of student exchanges.
Talking about his nation, is a great lead to supporting them and that is a great lead to the advantages of student exchanges.
His line of argumentation seems to be reliable and fluent.
That makes his points even more convincing.
The theme of the fourth paragraph (l. 13-17) is to break down walls (l. 13).
Here, the author talks a lot about togetherness and equality.
That forms a sense of togetherness not only between those two countries, but in the room he speaks in and between the people he speaks to.
In line 17 Barack uses the sentence And that's where the progress begins.
This phrase creates tension and is a great lead to the next paragraph!
The last paragraph (l. 20-23) is an appeal to the audience to be a part of global connections.
Because it is the last paragraph, his request stays in mind and gets underlined.
Barack Obama doesn't use any scientific or buissnessbusiness English.
He tries to stay understandable by using easy words but tries to be convincing at the same time.
He doesn't use much colloquial eathereither.
He stays professional.
Through the word deeply (l. 1), Obama underlines his interest to partner with Turkey.
Moreover, Barack uses words like passionate, engaged, [...], deeply informed (l. 8), supporting (l. 10), spirit of activism (l. 4) and productive and purposeful (l. 15).
All those words have deep meanings and everyone has aan imagination how passionate they are.
Obama uses these words to convince his audience, because they sound like forming quite good cooperation between Turkey and USA.
The ex-president uses a lot of stylistic devices.
The metaphor break down walls (l. 13) is used to make clear, how big intercultural connections are.
He uses this metaphor to make his point more vivid and understandable.
To break down walls, you need a lot of motivation and strength.
To get past stereotypes, you need that too.
In l. 4, 5 and 6 you can find the alliteration I've seen and I saw.
It gives the speachspeech a rythmrhythm and structure and makes it more interesting.
In l. 14, Obama uses the word common, two times.
Through that, he is able to form a convincing statement through explain his point in detail.
The direct advice So to all of you (l. 18), appeals to the audience's awarnessawareness.
They feel included and it forms a sense of togetherness.
In l. 21, the ex-president uses personal pronouns such as I and you.
Using personal pronouns in a speech forms a connection between speekerspeaker and listener, which creates a sense of trust.
To conclude, Barack Obama structures his speachspeech interesting and understandable.
The vivid stylistic devices help him to catch the audience's awarnessawareness and the choice of words fits the purpose of the text.
